title: Did Steph Curry and the Golden State Warriors Really Change the NBA?
text:
The biggest change in the last decade is the amount of threes NBA teams are taking. Before, 3-pointers were not the way NBA teams won games, but now if you want to win most teams look to outscore their opponent from 3.
Even though it has been proven that you can win an NBA championship by being reliant on hitting 3s. There are NBA fans that hate this style of play and believe the NBA is unwatchable.
NBA analysts believe Stephen Curry and the Golden State Warriors are to blame for this 3-point revolution. As they were the first NBA team to win an NBA championship in 2015 by being a 3-point heavy team. To add on to that their star back court duo were given the nickname the “Splash Brothers” because of how good they were at hitting shots from 3.
Yet, I believe there is another player and team that changed the NBA.
That is James Harden and the Houston Rockets, the Golden State Warriors biggest competitor during the years 2015-2019.
You probably think I am crazy, you probably think there is no way the Houston Rockets shot as many or even more threes than the Golden State Warriors, but trust me you will be surprised.
Here is a facet wrap comparing the number of 3-pointers attempted by both the Golden State Warriors and the Houston Rockets from 2014 to 2019.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
logs <- read_csv("data/Warriors_Rockets_3_Attempts.csv")
logsGOLHOU <- read_csv("data/Warriors_Rockets_3_Attempts.csv")
leagueaverage <- read_csv("data/Average_3_per_season_Real.csv")
logs24 <- read_csv("data/NBA_2023_2024_STATS.csv")
ggplot() +
  geom_line(
    data = logs,
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, group = Team)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = logs,
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`),
    size = 2  
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(20, 50)) +  
  facet_wrap(~Team, scales = "free_y", ncol = 4) +  
  labs(
    title = "The Houston Rockets reshaped the NBA with the 3-Point Revolution",
    subtitle = "James Harden and the Rockets transformed the NBA's 3-point game",
    y = "3 Point Attempts", x = "Year",
    caption = "By: Daniel Mahoney | Source: nba.com"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),  
    axis.text = element_text(size = 9),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.2)  
  )











Code
GOL <- logsGOLHOU |> filter(Team == "Golden State")
HOU <- logsGOLHOU |> filter(Team == "Houston")
ggplot() +
  geom_line(
    data = GOL, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Golden State"),  
  ) + 
  geom_line(
    data = HOU, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Houston"),  
  ) + 
  geom_line(
    data = leagueaverage, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "League Average"),  
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = GOL, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Golden State"),  
    size = 2, 
    shape = 16
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = HOU, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Houston"),  
    size = 2, 
    shape = 16
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = leagueaverage, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "League Average"),  
    size = 2, 
    shape = 16
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Golden State" = "blue", "Houston" = "red", "League Average" = "black")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(20, 50)) +
  labs(
    y = "Three Point Attempts", x = "Year",
    title = "No one took threes like the Houston Rockets",
    subtitle = "In the years 2014 to 2019, the Rockets were 1st in 3-pointers attempts five times in six years",
    caption = "Source: basketball reference | By Daniel Mahoney",  
    color = "Label"  
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2017, y = 40.7, label = "40.3"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2018, y = 42.7, label = "42.3"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2019, y = 45.8, label = "45.4"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),  
    axis.text = element_text(size = 9),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.2)  
  )











Code
GoodTeams <- logs24 |>  
  filter(Wins > 49) %>%
  group_by(Team)
ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data = logs24,
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      size = Wins
    ),
    alpha = .3
  ) + 
  geom_point(
    data = GoodTeams, 
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      size = Wins
    ),
    alpha = .3,
    color = "blue"
  ) + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data = GoodTeams,  
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      label = Team
    )
  ) +
  scale_size(range = c(3, 8), name = "Wins") +
  scale_size_continuous(
    breaks = c(45, 50, 55, 60),
    labels = c("45", "50", "55", "60"),
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Three Point Attempts",
    y = "Three Point Percentage",
    title = "While the NBA has evolved, the best teams still have their own identity",
    subtitle = "The most successful NBA teams have an identity shaped by their players",
    caption = "Source: nba.com | By Daniel Mahoney"
  ) +
  guides(size = guide_legend(title = "Wins", override.aes = list(color = "#333333"))) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),  
    axis.text = element_text(size = 9),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.2)  
  )

title: Were the Phoenix Suns Playoff-Worthy in 2014?
text:
The 2013-2014 NBA season was filled with unforgettable storylines: LeBron James played his final season with the Miami Heat, and the San Antonio Spurs beat the Heat to win their fifth NBA Championship in a Finals rematch.
However, people need to remember how competitive the Western Conference was during this dynamic NBA season. Eight teams won 49 games or more, and the 9th seed won 48 games but missed the playoffs.
That team was the Phoenix Suns. In a shocking turnaround, the Suns went from a sad 25 wins in 2013 to an impressive 48 wins in 2014, surpassing expectations.
This team should have made the 2014 playoffs.
The numbers tell the story!
Let’s start with net rating, a stat in the NBA that calculates point differential across 100 possessions. Good teams have a higher net rating, while bad teams have a lower net rating.
Here is the net rating of every Western Conference team during the 2013-2014 NBA season.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
library(ggbump)
logs14 <- read_csv("data/NBA_2013_2014_STATS.csv")
rankingsnba <- read_csv("data/Standing_By_Dates_West.csv")
WestNet <- logs14 |>
  filter(Conference == "West") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Net Rating` = mean(NETRTG),
    Wins = sum(W),  
    Losses = sum(L)      
  ) |>
  select(Team, Wins, Losses, `Net Rating`) |>
  arrange(desc(Wins)) 
WestNet |> 
 ungroup() |> 
  gt() |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "According to net rating, Phoenix was a top 8 team in the West",
    subtitle = "The Suns posted a better net rating than both the 7th seed and 8th seed in the West"
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Daniel Mahoney  |  **Source:** nba.com: Teams Advanced | Stats | NBA.com")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
    style = list(
      cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
      cell_text(weight = "bold", size = 12)
    )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |>
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#00538C"),
      cell_text(color = "white" )
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Dallas Mavericks"
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#00285E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Memphis Grizzlies"
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E56020"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Phoenix Suns"
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "green", weight = "bold"),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = c(`Net Rating`),
      rows = `Net Rating` > 0
    )
  ) |>
tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "red", weight = "normal"),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = c(`Net Rating`),
      rows = `Net Rating` < 0
    )
  )

Phoenix finished with the seventh-best net rating in the Western Conference in 2014, posting a rating of 2.6. This was higher than the Memphis Grizzlies and the Dallas Mavericks, two teams that ultimately made the playoffs.
In the last ten years, teams in the West that have been among the Top 8 in net rating in the conference have made the Western Conference playoffs 88.8% of the time.
The Suns’ success was driven by their elite offense, ranking in the Top 10 in several offensive categories.
They averaged 105.2 points per game, placing 7th in the NBA, and recorded an offensive rating of 108.2, which ranked 8th in the league. Offensive rating measures a team’s efficiency, showing how many points they score per 100 possessions.


Code
Points <- logs14 |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Points Per Game` = mean(PTS),         
    `Offensive Rating` = mean(OFFRTG),     
  )  
PointsSuns <- logs14 |>
  filter(Team == "Phoenix Suns") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Points Per Game` = mean(PTS),         
    `Offensive Rating` = mean(OFFRTG),     
  )  
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = Points, aes(x = `Points Per Game`, y = `Offensive Rating`), color="#768188") +
  geom_point(data = PointsSuns, aes(x = `Points Per Game`, y = `Offensive Rating`), color="#FBAF6F", size = 2.5) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = PointsSuns, 
    aes(x = `Points Per Game`, y = `Offensive Rating`, label = Team),
    hjust = 0.5,   
    vjust = 0.5  
  ) + 
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 104.4, y = 111.5, label = "Good Scoring, Strong Rating"), 
    color = "#333333", face = "bold", 
    hjust = 0.5, 
    vjust = 0.5   
  ) +
  geom_text(

    color = "#333333", face = "bold",
    hjust = 0.5,

  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 97, y = 111.5, label = "Bad Scoring, Strong Rating"), 
    color = "#333333", face = "bold",
    hjust = 0.5,  
    vjust = 0.5   
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 104.4, y = 100, label = "Good Scoring, Weak Rating"), 
    color = "#333333", face = "bold",
    hjust = 0.5,  
    vjust = 0.5   
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x = "Points Per Game",
    y = "Offensive Rating", 
    title = "The Suns were dominate offensively",
    subtitle = " Phoenix ranked Top 10 in both points per game and offensive rating",
    caption = "Source: nba.com | By Daniel Mahoney"
  ) +
  theme(
    title = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 16, face = 'bold'),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#F4D3EC"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 101, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 105.7, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +
  annotate("text", x = 101, y = 105.7, label = "League Average", color = "black", size = 4, fontface = "bold")









The Arizona-based team was also highly efficient in its shooting, ranking 8th in both field goal and three-point percentage. Shooting 46.3% from the field and 37.2% from beyond the arc.


Code
ShootingPer <- logs14 |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Field Goal Percentage` = mean(`FG%`, na.rm = TRUE),  
    `Three Point Percentage` = mean(`3P%`, na.rm = TRUE) 
  )
ShootingPerSuns <- logs14 |>
  filter(Team == "Phoenix Suns") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Field Goal Percentage` = mean(`FG%`, na.rm = TRUE),  
    `Three Point Percentage` = mean(`3P%`, na.rm = TRUE) 
  )
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = ShootingPer, aes(x = `Field Goal Percentage`, y = `Three Point Percentage`), color="#768188") +
  geom_point(data = ShootingPerSuns, aes(x = `Field Goal Percentage`, y = `Three Point Percentage`), color="#FBAF6F", size = 2.5) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = ShootingPerSuns, 
    aes(x = `Field Goal Percentage`, y = `Three Point Percentage`, label = Team),
    hjust = 0.5,   
    vjust = 0.5,   
  ) + 
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 48, y = 39, label = "Efficient"), 
    color = "#333333", face = "bold",
    hjust = 0.5,  
    vjust = 0.5  
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 44, y = 39, label = "Efficient from Three"), 
    color = "#333333", face = "bold",
    hjust = 0.5,  
    vjust = 0.5   
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 48, y = 32.2, label = "Efficient from the Field"), 
    color = "#333333", face = "bold",
    hjust = 0.5,  
    vjust = 0.5   
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 44.1, y = 32.2, label = "Inefficient"), 
    color = "#333333", face = "bold",
    hjust = 0.5,  
    vjust = 0.5   
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
     x = "Field Goal Percentage",
    y = "Three Point Percentage", 
    title = "Phoenix's flawless execution led to efficiency",
    subtitle = "The valley's team ranked Top 10 in field goal and three point percentage",
    caption = "Source: nba.com | By Daniel Mahoney"
  ) +
  theme(
     title = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 16, face = 'bold'),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#F4D3EC"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 45.4, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 35.9, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +
annotate("text", x = 45.4, y = 35.9, label = "League Average", color = "black", size = 4, fontface = "bold")









In 2014, only three teams finished in the Top 10 in points per game, offensive rating, field goal percentage, and three-point percentage. Two teams, the San Antonio Spurs and the Dallas Mavericks, made the playoffs, while the third team, the Phoenix Suns, missed the playoffs.
Another factor that needs to be talked about is how tough the West was compared to the East.
What if the Suns were in the East? Would they be able to stand out?
This bubble chart, with the dot size scaled by the number of wins, shows that the Suns would have been exceptional in the East, especially compared to the teams that made the Eastern Conference playoffs (the teams that are labeled).


Code
EastNet <- logs14 |>
  filter(Conference == "East") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Offensive Rating` = mean(OFFRTG),
    `Defensive Rating` = mean(DEFRTG),
    Wins = sum(W)
  ) |>
  select(Team, Wins, `Offensive Rating`, `Defensive Rating`) |>
  arrange(desc(Wins))  
EastNetPlayoffs <- logs14 %>%
  filter(Conference == "East") %>%
  filter(W > 37) %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarise(
    `Offensive Rating` = mean(OFFRTG, na.rm = TRUE),
    `Defensive Rating` = mean(DEFRTG, na.rm = TRUE),
    Wins = sum(W, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) %>%
  select(Team, Wins, `Offensive Rating`, `Defensive Rating`) %>%
  arrange(desc(Wins))
 Phoenix <- logs14 |>
  filter(Team == "Phoenix Suns") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Offensive Rating` = mean(OFFRTG),
    `Defensive Rating` = mean(DEFRTG),
    Wins = sum(W)
  ) |>
  select(Team, Wins, `Offensive Rating`, `Defensive Rating`) |>
  arrange(desc(Wins))
ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = Phoenix, aes(x = `Offensive Rating`, y = `Defensive Rating`, size = Wins), alpha = .75, color = "#E55B00") +
  geom_point(data = EastNet, aes(x = `Offensive Rating`, y = `Defensive Rating`, size = Wins), alpha = .75, color = "#999999") +
  geom_point(data = EastNetPlayoffs, aes(x = `Offensive Rating`, y = `Defensive Rating`, size = Wins), alpha = .6, color = "#D85A5A") +
  geom_text(data = Phoenix, aes(x = `Offensive Rating`, y = `Defensive Rating`, label = Team), hjust = 0.5, vjust = -1, size = 3) +
  geom_text(data = EastNetPlayoffs, aes(x = `Offensive Rating`, y = `Defensive Rating`, label = Team), hjust = 0.5, vjust = -1.5, size = 2) +
  annotate("text", x = 108, y = 110, label = "Better Offensive Teams", color = "#333333", size = 3) +
  annotate("text", x = 108, y = 101.7, label = "Balanced Teams", color = "#333333", size = 3) +
  annotate("text", x = 101, y = 110, label = "Struggling Teams", color = "#333333", size = 3) +
  annotate("text", x = 101, y = 101.7, label = "Better Defensive Teams", color = "#333333", size = 3) +
  annotate("text", x = 104.1, y = 105.2, label = "The Average", color = "black", size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate("text", x = 108, y = 107.2, label = "Both Teams Won 48 Games", color = "#333333", size = 3.3, fontface = "bold") +
  geom_encircle(data=Phoenix, aes(x=`Offensive Rating`-0.2, y=`Defensive Rating`), s_shape=.01, expand=.0000000003, colour="red") +
  labs(
    x = "Offensive Rating (Higher is Better)",
    y = "Defensive Rating (Lower is Better)",
    title = "Phoenix would have dominated the East",  
    subtitle = "With 48 wins, the Suns would have been tied for the 3rd seed in the weaker conference",  
    caption = "Source: nba.com | By Daniel Mahoney",  
    size = "Wins"  
  ) +
  scale_size_continuous(
    breaks = c(30, 36, 42, 48),
    labels = c("30", "36", "42", "48"),
    range = c(2, 6)
  ) +
  guides(size = guide_legend(title = "Wins", override.aes = list(color = "#333333"))) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 16, face = 'bold'),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#F4D3EC"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 11),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "right",
  ) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 104.1, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 105.6, linetype = "dashed", color = "black")









Only one team in the East had a better offensive rating than the Phoenix Suns, the Miami Heat, who had the star trio of LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, and Chris Bosh.
Additionally, it is worth noting that the third-seeded Toronto Raptors finished with the same number of wins as the Suns. Meanwhile, the Atlanta Hawks finished with 38 wins but still made the NBA Playoffs as the 8th seed.
What is interesting is that the Suns finished with the same number of wins as the Raptors. Even though the Suns played 52 games against the West and 30 games against the East, the team from Canada played 52 games against the East and 30 games against the West.
Imagine if Phoenix was in the East, and 52 of their opponents were against teams in the East. They would have easily surpassed 48 wins.
However, the Phoenix Suns did enough to make the playoffs in the West. There were stretches during the season when they were in the playoff picture.


Code
team_colors <- c(
  "#A9A9A9",  # San Antonio
  "#87CEEB", # Oklahoma City
  "#C8102E", # Los Angeles
  "#000000", # Houston
   "#D2691E", # Portland
  "#FFC72C", # Golden State
  "#E56020",  # Phoenix
  "#00538C", # Dallas
  "#00285E"  # Memphis
)
team_color_map <- setNames(team_colors, unique(rankingsnba$Team))
ggplot(data = rankingsnba, aes(x = Date, y = Rank, color = Team, group = Team)) +
  geom_bump(size = 1) +  
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = team_color_map) +  
  scale_y_reverse(breaks = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9)) +  
  labs(
    title = "Phoenix playoff hopes vanished during the final week", 
    subtitle = "The Suns held the 7th seed until the final week of the regular season, falling to 9th",
    caption = "Source: basketballreference.com | By Daniel Mahoney",
    x = "Date", 
    y = "Playoff Seed", 
    color = "Team"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    title = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 15, face = 'bold'),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#F4D3EC"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "#5D1F8E", size = 11),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









The Suns picked the worst possible time to slump, losing three of their final four games. The losses to the Dallas Mavericks and Memphis Grizzlies proved to cost them. On April 12th, Phoenix fell to the Mavericks 101-98, followed by a 97-91 loss to the Grizzlies just two days later.
Those two teams were competing with the Suns for playoff positioning, and if Phoenix had won both games, we would have seen this Suns team in the 2014 NBA playoffs.
